content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. REMOVAL OF PROVISIONS RESTRICTING TRADE AND OTHER RELATIONS WITH CUBA." is about removing restrictions on trade and other relations with Cuba. The authorities for embargo and sugar quota under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 are repealed. The President's authorities under the Trading With the Enemy Act with respect to Cuba will no longer be exercised. Any export prohibitions to Cuba in effect before the effective date of the Act will be removed. On the effective date of this Act, export controls on Cuba under the Export Administration Act of 1979 will cease. The President can impose new export restrictions on Cuba under various acts and exercise emergency powers due to a newly perceived threat to national security, foreign policy, or the economy. The Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 and the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 are repealed, with corresponding amendments to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. The Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 and the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 are repealed, along with amendments to various sections of different acts, including the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 and the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996, along with related amendments, are repealed. Additionally, Section 902(c) of the Food Security Act of 1985 is also repealed. Any common carrier authorized to install, maintain, and repair telecommunications equipment and facilities in Cuba, and provide telecommunications services between the United States and Cuba, including upgrading facilities and equipment. SEC. 3. TRAVEL. Travel to and from Cuba by U.S. citizens or residents, and related transactions, may not be regulated if lawful in the U.S. Transactions include those related to travel or maintenance in Cuba, and banking transactions involving foreign currency. The United States Postal Service is required to establish direct mail service to and from Cuba, utilizing charter providers if necessary. Federal assistance is prohibited in this matter. No Federal funds can be used to provide assistance to Cuba, including grants, sales, guaranties, insurance, loans, leases, credits, or reserves on terms more favorable than the market. This includes assistance from the Export-Import Bank of the United States for exports to or imports from Cuba. The US prohibits the use of federal funds for assistance to Cuba, including insurance, financing, and investment. This also applies to assistance from the Export-Import Bank for exports to or imports from Cuba. The US prohibits federal funds for assistance to Cuba, including financing under the Agricultural Trade Act of 1978 and loans for transactions involving confiscated property. Additionally, Cuban debt can be exchanged, reduced, or forgiven for an equity interest. The US prohibits federal funds for assistance to Cuba, including financing under the Agricultural Trade Act of 1978 and loans for transactions involving confiscated property. Cuban debt can be exchanged, reduced, or forgiven for an equity interest in a property, investment, or operation of the Government of Cuba or a Cuban national. The term "agency or instrumentality of the Government of Cuba" refers to an agency or instrumentality of a foreign state as defined in section 1603(b) of title 28, United States Code, with references to "a foreign state" deemed to be a reference to Cuba. The Act will become effective 60 days after its enactment.
